title: Is it just me who likes male teachers better than female teachers? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am a female teacher. I have noticed that students, mostly boys, respond better to male teachers. It may be this way because men have stronger voices and tend to use authority more so than a female teacher. It may have to do with what children are taught at home regarding males and females and how you should regard them. my favorite teacher was a male. It wasn’t because of any other reason than he was the best teacher I had in my entire education. He cared and he worked very hard at his job. We didn’t just read books, we lived books. One particular example was a book we read called, Alive:The Story of the Andes Survivors, a true story about a plane filled with a rugby team that crashed in the Andes mountains and they climbed their way out after 70 days on the mountain. Our teacher had us tightly packed, sitting on the floor among upturned desks and chairs while reading the book, just like the survivors in the book were tightly packed among each other and debris in the fuselage. He had rags that we tied around our heads and arms and legs just like the survivors with their real injuries. He even opened the windows to the classroom in the midst of winter to get the feeling of being so cold, just as the survivors were. Our teacher brought that book, and others, to life for us. He was truly a great teacher and I remember his lessons both about life and reading to this day. I don’t know why you like your male teachers better than your female teachers, but both have qualities that you can gain from. I would suggest looking for the best in your teachers as opposed to what you may not like about them. Everyone has something to offer.

Honestly depends on the pupil. I was at an all boys’ school - and was gay. Closeted, unsure - but gay. I only ever managed to get on with the male teachers who weren’t growly, butch, with something to prove, even to eleven year old boys such as myself. My mother very quickly noticed that generally I got higher marks and had less trouble, in the classes with non-sporty male teachers, and, particularly, female teachers. In fact, in one case, the English teacher I had for four and a half years out of seven - well, more like her, and I would’ve come out of that school top of every class. I believe my mother’s words were “God, she LOVES you - think she’d adopt you if she could!” No surprise then that my very best exam results came from the classes she taught me, without exception. (And as for my one time geography teacher, form tutor, and school rugby coach - well, when your own mother comes home and utters the words “Just ignore that arsehole…”!) And if anyone thinks it was just luck, let me point to my French studies. I excelled at languages, having started with a gentle, kind male teacher, continued with a female teacher - and was close to top marks at GCSE. However, come A-Level, and those teachers gave way to much more “manly” a man - in his own mind at least. And at that point, my French grades dropped from top As to Ds. Mum couldn’t work out why, until parents’ evening - when she met the man in question. Such a shame he had to take six months’ leave just as A-level season began - replaced by the gentler guy, I clawed my way back up to a C. I do wish it wasn’t that straightforward, but seriously. It’s really not so hard to just be the same with all pupils, regardless of whether they’re into school sports or not. Still, 21 years later, I’d just say - Mrs Seddon, you were a bloody legend. And Mr McKie? Go fuck yourself seventeen ways to Tuesday.
